field_edited_text.value:
UL

Harbor Route and Related Proposals

'B'E'R'E'R'E'E'R'E'ER'



major traffic arteries and widening would be highly desirable.
Widening without the Expressway would be expensive and would,
in any event, necessitate the demolition of most of the buildings
between the two streets. With the Expressway, widening be-
comes a relatively simple and relatively inexpensive by-product.

4, The Northern Route from the western City boundary to Myrtle
Avenue combined with the Harbor Route from Myrtle Avenue to
the east provides the closest possible access to many portions of
the central business district, including particularly the retail trade
center surrounding the intersection of Howard and Lexington
Streets.

At Myrtle Avenue the Harbor Route deviates from the Northern
Route. It turns south and continues in this direction as a depressed route
to Pratt Street, running first between Myrtle Avenue and Pine Street and
then skirting the western boundary of the University of Maryland Re-
newal Area.

At the lower end of this southerly stretch the proposed route is occu-
pied by St. Paul’s Cemetery which lies between Redwood and Lombard
Streets just east of Fremont Avenue. This cemetery dates back to 1800
and contains the graves of a number of noted men. It would be desirable
to avoid this cemetery, but it does not appear possible to do so. Moving
the Expressway to the east would conflict with the University of Maryland
and University Hospital. A relocation to the west would increase sub-
stantially the number and quality of houses to be razed, would eliminate
the possibility of creating an inner ring around the downtown area, and
would destroy any useful relationship between the expressway system and
the retail trade center.

Several solutions to this situation are possible. If St. Paul’s Church
agreed, the Expressway, depressed at this point, could be tunneled far

39

enough below the Cemetery so as not to disturb the graves. Or possibly
the Church and the City might find it mutually advantageous to consider
the removal of the cemetery to a wholly new site. The problem, which
has evident emotional overtones, will have to be worked out in conjunction
with the Church Vestry.

After passing under the Cemetery the Harbor Route swings around
to the east and continues between Pratt and Camden Streets as far as
Light Street. As it makes this turn from south to east it is also rising to
an elevated structure so as to clear a very large sewer in Penn Street and
the Baltimore and Ohio tunnel under Howard Street. (It continues as
an elevated structure for the balance of the route primarily because it
skirts the northern side of the Inner Harbor and in this location a de-
pressed roadway would be below the water line.) Also, as the Harbor
Route turns to the east connections are provided to Russell Street to the
south so that there is easy access between the Harbor Route and the
Washington-Baltimore Expressway.

As the Harbor Route proceeds between Pratt and Camden Streets it
first passes along the southern boundary of the University of Maryland
Renewal Area, thus serving as a buffer between the proposed University
campus and the industrial area to the south. It then passes within one
block of the Civic Center and Charles Center and access ramps are pro-
vided which would serve both of these new developments. Renewal Area 7
and the Camden B&O Station lie immediately to the south of this stretch
of the Expressway.

The clearance of the blocks between Pratt and Camden Streets pro-
vides the opportunity, if desired, to widen both streets and to utilize the
balance of the land for off-street parking, for landscaping, or for similar
purposes. The cleared land on either side of the Expressway would furnish
an excellent opportunity to plant street trees in accordance with the
